{
  "article_text": [
    "stochastic volatility models are prominent in option valuation literature as they are able to coalesce many stylized facts about volatility namely volatility smile , mean reversion , volatility clustering etc.(eg .",
    "see bakshi , cao and chen @xmath0 , bates @xmath1 , chernov and ghysels @xmath1 , gatheral @xmath2etc . ) .",
    "single factor stochastic volatility models are being discussed in many papers(eg .",
    "see hull and white @xmath3 , stein - stein @xmath4 , heston @xmath5 , ball - roma @xmath6 etc . ) .",
    "volatility smile can be generated by single factor stochastic volatility models but its time varying nature remains unexplained by these models .",
    "+ christoffersen et al .",
    "@xmath7 strongly argued the need of multifactor stochastic volatility models to capture some of the most salient stylized facts in index options .",
    "they demonstrated the role of multiple factors in capturing term structure and moneyness effects .",
    "+ multifactor stochastic volatility models are much recent and very significant in option valuation literature .",
    "alizadeh et al .",
    "@xmath8 found the evidence of two factors in volatility with one highly persistent factor and other quickly mean reverting factor .",
    "extending this idea , fouque et al .",
    "@xmath9 proposed a two factor stochastic volatility model with one fast mean reverting factor and another slowly varying factor .",
    "they have showed that slow varying volatility factor is essential for options with longer maturity and used perturbation analysis in context of pricing options . for more details",
    "one can refer fouque et al .",
    "@xmath10 . as persistence of volatility should be given importance and must be incorporated in any volatility model ( robert f engle et al .",
    "@xmath11 ) and knowing the fact that multifactor stochastic volatility models give better results for the options with medium - longer maturity ( fatone et al .",
    "@xmath7 ) , the slow factor of volatility , which is highly persistent , is important and its dynamics can not be ignored . also in perturbation analysis given by fouque et al .",
    "@xmath9 the approximate option price depends upon slow factor of volatility but independent of fast factor .",
    "+ we propose a multifactor model to give importance to slow factor of volatility by taking it mean reverting and approximating it by a parabolic arc .",
    "also , with this model we have derived the pricing formula for european call options .",
    "we have also introduced the notion of modified black scholes operator .",
    "the paper is organised as follows : in section @xmath12 we introduce the multifactor stochastic volatility model .",
    "option pricing equation and asymptotic expansion of price is discussed in section @xmath13 and @xmath14 respectively .",
    "approximate price of european option is given in section @xmath15 and section @xmath16 includes the conclusion .",
    "let @xmath17 be the price of underlying asset ( non dividend paying ) , @xmath18 be the risk neutral probability measure and r be the risk free rate of interest . under @xmath18 ,",
    "the dynamics of @xmath17 be given by a diffusion process as : @xmath19 here , @xmath20 is stochastic volatility driven by two factors @xmath21 and @xmath22 which are respectively the fast scale and slow scale factors of volatility .",
    "@xmath23 is standard brownian motion .",
    "we consider the dynamics of fast volatility factor @xmath21 as given in fouque et al .",
    "@xmath9 : @xmath24 which is an ornstein - uhlenbeck ( ou ) process with long run distribution @xmath25 and is reverting on the short time scale @xmath26 around its long run mean value @xmath27 with @xmath28 as its rate of mean reversion . its volatility of volatility ( vol - vol ) parameter is @xmath29 .",
    "@xmath30 is standard brownian motion .",
    "+ @xmath23 and @xmath30 have the correlation structure :    @xmath31 = \\rho_{xy } dt\\ ] ]    where , @xmath32 represents the correlation between two standard brownian motions .",
    "slow factor of volatility is persistent and empirically it is mean reverting too . but mean reversion can be clearly observed for long term options .",
    "we take quadratic arc approximation to capture slow volatility factor given by : @xmath33 where @xmath34 represents the error term in the approximation of @xmath35 with @xmath36 .",
    "we can justify this approximation of persistent factor of volatility , @xmath22 from @xmath37 historic volatility data given in     to september @xmath38 , clearly mean reverting about 20@xmath39(say),width=302 ]    fig.[hisvol ] + we are also justifying this choice of approximation by considering slow volatility factor @xmath22 to follow a diffusion process : @xmath40 where @xmath41 is also a standard brownian motion having the correlation structure with @xmath23 and @xmath30 as :    @xmath42 =   \\rho_{xz } dt\\ ] ] @xmath43= \\rho_{yz}dt\\ ] ] where the correlation coefficients @xmath44 and @xmath45 are such that @xmath46 and @xmath47 for the positive definiteness of the covariance matrix of three brownian motions .",
    "+ here , @xmath22 follows ornstein - uhlenbeck ( ou)process with long run distribution @xmath48 and is reverting on long time scale @xmath49 around its long run mean value @xmath50 .",
    "the rate of mean reversion for @xmath22 is @xmath51 and its vol - vol parameter is @xmath52 .",
    "+ on solving , @xmath53 becomes : @xmath54t^2+[-k(z_{0}-m^{'})]t+z_{0}+\\delta_{t}+\\beta_{t}\\ ] ] comparing it with @xmath55 , we obtain @xmath56    @xmath57    @xmath58    and @xmath59    here,@xmath60 represents the initial value of slow factor of volatility . to assure that @xmath36 we assume that @xmath61 .",
    "@xmath62 is the truncation error and @xmath63 involving @xmath52 , is randomness in the value of slow factor of volatility @xmath22 .",
    "+ we are assuming here that the error term @xmath34 is negligible as truncation error can be neglected and vol - vol parameter @xmath52 of slow factor of volatility can be neglected under parabolic approximation .    the approximated value of @xmath22 is a function of t. also , @xmath64 and @xmath65\\ ] ] where ,    @xmath66 .    these expressions will be needed for pricing in the upcoming sections .",
    "so in the nutshell , our multifactor stochastic volatility model under risk neutral probability measure @xmath18 , which is already chosen by the market is : @xmath19",
    "@xmath24 @xmath67 where , @xmath56 @xmath57 @xmath68    which we have obtained by considering diffusion process @xmath40 for @xmath35 .",
    "next we ll write the pricing equation for european options .",
    "the price of european call option with payoff function @xmath69 under the risk neutral probability measure @xmath18 is conditional expectation of discounted payoff given as : @xmath70 by feynman - kac formula , @xmath71 satisfies the following parabolic pde : @xmath72 with the boundary condition @xmath73 where the operator @xmath74 is given by : @xmath75 with @xmath76 @xmath77 and @xmath78 on putting the value of @xmath79 and @xmath80 from @xmath81 and @xmath82 in @xmath83 and @xmath84 and on solving , we get @xmath85,\\ ] ] and @xmath86\\frac{\\partial}{\\partial{t}}+\\frac{1}{2}f^{2}(y , z)x^{2}\\frac{\\partial^{2}}{\\partial x^{2}}+r(x\\frac{\\partial}{\\partial x}- .)\\\\&\\nonumber+\\biggl(\\frac{\\rho_{xz}\\eta f(y , z)x}{2\\mathcal{a}t+\\mathcal{b}+\\zeta_t}\\biggr ) \\frac{\\partial^{2}}{\\partial x\\partial t}+\\frac{1}{2}\\eta^{2}\\frac{1}{(2\\mathcal{a}t+\\mathcal{b}+\\zeta_t)^{2}}\\frac{\\partial^{2}}{\\partial t^{2}}\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] where , @xmath87 is given by @xmath88 + from @xmath89 and @xmath90 we have , @xmath91 this is the required pricing equation where @xmath92 is the solution of above parabolic pde .",
    "for asymptotic expansion , expand @xmath92 in powers of @xmath93 , i.e. @xmath94 using it in @xmath95 gives @xmath96 similar expansion is considered in fouque et al .",
    "@xmath97 for single factor and for two factors of volatility respectively .",
    "we have considered the expansion in powers of @xmath93 only because we have approximated the slow factor of volatility .",

    "+ equation @xmath171 gives the required first order approximation of option price @xmath92 where , @xmath172 such that @xmath173 converges to zero at maturity .",
    "+ we name @xmath174 as modification factor .",
    "we are interested in its value .",
    "numerically , if we take @xmath175 , for @xmath176 and @xmath177 , we get @xmath178 .",
    "it will significantly improve the pricing .",
    "we have used the market data to obtain these parameters .",
    "the accuracy of this first order approximation and calibration of effective stochastic volatility parameter @xmath179 can be done as already explained in fouque et al .",
    "slow factor of volatility is persistent and its dynamics ca nt be ignored .",
    "no doubt it is stochastic , but approximating it with a deterministic arc makes the calculation easy and give a simplified expression for the price of european call option .",
    "this price is perturbed around the modified black - scholes price .",
    "we have also given the expression of modified price in terms of black - scholes price and have calculated the modification factor using s@xmath138p @xmath139 index options data .              .",
    "christoffersen , p . ,",
    "s.heston and k.jacobs(the shape and term structure of index option smirk : why multifactor stochastic volatility models work so well ) _ management science _",
    "vol.55 , 1914  1932 , 2009 .    .",
    "chernov , m. and e.ghysels(a study towards a unified approach to the joint estimation of objective and risk neutral measures for the purpose of option valuation ) _ management science _",
    "vol.56 , no.3 , 407  458 , 2000 ."
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> in the present work , we propose a new multifactor stochastic volatility model in which slow factor of volatility is approximated by a parabolic arc . we retain ourselves to the perturbation technique to obtain approximate expression for european option prices . </S>",
    "<S> we introduce the notion of modified black - scholes price . </S>",
    "<S> we obtain a simplified expression for european option price which is perturbed around the modified black - scholes price and have also obtained the expression of modified price in terms of black - scholes price .    </S>",
    "<S> keywords : multifactor stochastic volatility ; slow volatility factor ; quadratic approximation ; volatility model ; option pricing + ams subject classifications : 34e13 , 60h15 , 60h30 , 60j60 , 91b70 , 91g20 , 91g80 </S>"
  ]
}
